# The Twelve Spies

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tissot_The_Grapes_of_Canaan.jpg/240px-
Tissot_The_Grapes_of_Canaan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tissot_The_Grapes_of_Canaan.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tissot_The_Grapes_of_Canaan.jpg "Enlarge")

_The Grapes of Canaan_ by [James Tissot](/wiki/James_Tissot "James Tissot").
Although the spies brought back a cluster of grapes so large that it took two
men to carry it (Numbers 13:23), only two of the twelve brought back a good
report of the land.

**The Twelve Spies** (Hebrew: שנים עשר המרגלים), as recorded in the [Book of
Numbers](/wiki/Book_of_Numbers "Book of Numbers"), were a group of
[Israelite](/wiki/Israelites "Israelites") chieftains, one from each of the
[Twelve Tribes](/wiki/Israelites#Biblical_Israel "Israelites"), who were
dispatched by [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") to scout out the Land of
[Canaan](/wiki/Canaan "Canaan") for 40 days[1] as a future home for the
Israelite people, during the time when the Israelites were in the wilderness
following their [Exodus](/wiki/The_Exodus "The Exodus") from [Ancient
Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt"). The account is found in [Numbers
13:1-33](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0413.htm#1).

God had promised [Abraham](/wiki/Abraham "Abraham") that there would be a
[Promised Land](/wiki/Promised_Land "Promised Land") for the nations to come
out of his son, [Isaac](/wiki/Isaac "Isaac"). The land of Canaan which the
spies were to explore was the same Promised Land. Moses asked for an
assessment of the geographical features of the land, the strength and numbers
of the population, the agricultural potential and actual performance of the
land, civic organization (whether their cities were like camps or
strongholds), and [forestry](/wiki/Forestry "Forestry") conditions. He also
asked them to be positive in their outlook and to return with samples of local
produce.

When ten of the twelve spies showed little faith in the doom and gloom report
they gave about the land, they were slandering what they believed God had
promised them. They did not believe that God could help them, and the people
as a whole were persuaded that it was not possible to take the land. As a
result, the entire nation was made to wander in the desert for 40 years, until
almost the entire generation of men had died.[2] [Joshua](/wiki/Joshua
"Joshua") and [Caleb](/wiki/Caleb "Caleb") were the two spies who brought back
a good report and believed that God would help them succeed. They were the
only men from their generation permitted to go into the Promised Land after
the time of wandering.[3]

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 About the spies
  * 2 Consequences
  * 3 Tisha B'Av
  * 4 References

## About the
spies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Twelve_Spies&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: About the spies")]

God had promised the Israelites that they would be able to conquer the land
with its indigenous Canaanite nations. [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") instructed
the spies to report back on the agriculture and lay of the land. However,
during their tour, the spies saw fortified cities and resident giants, which
frightened them and led them to believe that the Israelites would not be able
to conquer the land as God had promised. Ten of the spies decided to bring
back an unbalanced report, emphasizing the difficulty of the task before
them.[4]

> They gave Moses this account, "We went into the land to which you sent us,
> and it does flow with milk and honey! Here is its fruit. But the people who
> live there are very powerful, and the cities are fortified and very large.
> We even saw descendants of [Anak](/wiki/Anak "Anak") there."
>
> — Numbers, 13:27-28

Two of the spies — Joshua and Caleb — did not go along with the majority and
tried to convince the Israelites that they could conquer the land:

> Then Caleb silenced the people before Moses and said, "We should go up and
> take possession of the land, for we can certainly do it."
>
> — Numbers, 13:30

However, the Israelite community believed the majority's conclusions. All of
the spies, except Joshua and Caleb, were struck down with a plague and
died.[5]

[Joshua](/wiki/Joshua "Joshua") was at first a fierce warrior. He was chosen
as the representative from his tribe, [Ephraim](/wiki/Tribe_of_Ephraim "Tribe
of Ephraim"), to explore the land of Canaan, and was in agreement with Caleb
that the Promised Land could be conquered. After the incident with the 12
spies, Joshua lived through the 40 year wandering period, and was named
successor to Moses as instructed by God. Joshua completed the task of leading
the Israelites into the Promised Land and of taking possession of it. Joshua
also was the leader in renewing the Mosaic covenant with their God.[6]

[Caleb](/wiki/Caleb "Caleb") was from the tribe of Judah. He was also chosen
to explore the land of Canaan, and he was (along with Joshua) the other man
who said that the God of Israel could help the Israelite people to victory
against the Canaanites. God promised Caleb and Joshua that they would receive
the land which they had explored for themselves and their descendants. Caleb
was also told that he would live to go into the Promised Land.[7]

The names of the twelve spies were:[8]

  1. Shammua son of Zaccur, from the tribe of Reuben
  2. Shaphat son of Hori, from the tribe of Simeon
  3. Caleb son of Jephunneh, from the tribe of Judah
  4. Igal son of Joseph, from the tribe of Issachar
  5. Hoshea (Joshua) son of Nun, from the tribe of Ephraim
  6. Palti son of Raphu, from the tribe of Benjamin
  7. Gaddiel son of Sodi, from the tribe of Zebulin
  8. Gaddi son of Susi, from the tribe of Manasseh
  9. Ammiel son of Gemalli, from the tribe of Dan
  10. Sethur son of Michael, from the tribe of Asher
  11. Nahbi son of Vophsi, from the tribe of Naphtali
  12. Geuel son of Maki, from the tribe of Gad

Some people think the word "spies" is an incorrect translation. The Hebrew
word that the Torah uses is מרגלים ("meraglim"), which can also mean
"traitors" or "deserters". In [Numbers 13:](http://www.mechon-
mamre.org/p/pt/pt0413.htm#), the Hebrew word describing the group is also the
word usually translated as "men" or the word usually translated as "princes".
In addition, the twelve were clearly not trained as spies, nor did they
conduct any covert activity, nor did they enlist any indigenous people for
later help. Thus, the phrase "Twelve Scouts" or "Twelve Observers" might be an
alternative way of describing the group. However, the final point remains that
their "report" resulted in a great outcry and the Israelites despaired of
entering the promised land and were punished by God accordingly, as outlined
above.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

##
Consequences[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Twelve_Spies&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Consequences")]

The Israelites' belief of the false report amounted to the acceptance of
[lashon hara](/wiki/Lashon_hara "Lashon hara") (lit." "evil tongue" /
"slander" in Hebrew) against the [Land of Israel](/wiki/Land_of_Israel "Land
of Israel").

> But the men who had gone up with him said, "We can't attack those people;
> they are stronger than we are." And they spread a bad report about the land
> they had explored. They said, "The land we explored devours those living in
> it. All the people we saw there were of great size. We saw the Nephilim
> there (the descendants of Anak come from the Nephilim). We seemed like
> grasshoppers in our own eyes, and we looked the same to them."
>
> — Numbers, 13:31-33

This was considered a grave sin by God. Corresponding to the 40 days that the
spies toured the land, God decreed that the Israelites would wander in the
wilderness for 40 years as a result of their unwillingness to take the land.
Moreover, the entire generation of men who left [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt")
during the [Exodus](/wiki/The_Exodus "The Exodus") would die in the desert,
save for Joshua and Caleb who did not slander the land.[2]

For 40 years, the Israelites wandered in the wilderness, eating
[quail](/wiki/Quail "Quail") and [manna](/wiki/Manna "Manna"). They were led
into the Promised Land by Joshua; the [victory at
Jericho](/wiki/Battle_of_Jericho "Battle of Jericho") marked the beginning of
possession of the land. As victories were won, the tracts of land were
assigned to each tribe, and they lived peacefully with each other. God brought
victories where needed, and his promise to Abraham was fulfilled.

## Tisha B'Av[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Twelve_Spies&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Tisha B'Av")]

According to Rabbinic tradition (as seen in the [Mishnah
Taanit](/wiki/Ta%27anit "Ta'anit") 4:6), the sin of the spies produced the
annual fast day of [Tisha B'Av](/wiki/Tisha_B%27Av "Tisha B'Av"). When the
Israelites accepted the false report, they wept over the false belief that God
was setting them up for defeat. The night that the people cried was the ninth
of [Av](/wiki/Av "Av"), which became a day of weeping and misfortune for all
time.[9]

[Rashi](/wiki/Rashi "Rashi"), commenting on [Numbers 13:25](http://www.mechon-
mamre.org/p/pt/pt0413.htm#25), notes that the journey was shortened by God, as
God foresaw their downfall and subsequent proportionate punishment (1 day
equaling 1 year).[10]

qa.question: who took the israelites to the promised land

nq_2757_0.Query Analysis: The query asks about the leader who led the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_0.Answer Analysis: The answer is Joshua, indicating that he was the leader who took the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_0.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the Twelve Spies, a group of Israelite chieftains sent by Moses to scout the Land of Canaan. It mentions the context of the Israelites being in the wilderness after their Exodus from Egypt and God's promise of a Promised Land to Abraham.
nq_2757_0.Key Information Matching: The document provides context about the Israelites and the Promised Land but does not directly address who led them there.
nq_2757_0.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not mention Joshua or directly state who led the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_0.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides background information about the Israelites and their journey towards the Promised Land, which is relevant to the broader context of the query.
nq_2757_0.Explanation: The document is partially relevant as it provides context about the Israelites and the Promised Land, which are key elements of the query. However, it lacks specific information about Joshua, the leader who actually took the Israelites to the Promised Land, making it unable to directly answer the query.

nq_2757_2.Query Analysis: The query asks for the individual(s) who led the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_2.Answer Analysis: The answer identifies Joshua as the person who took the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_2.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the story of the twelve spies sent by Moses to scout the Promised Land. It highlights the lack of faith shown by ten of the spies and the positive report given by Joshua and Caleb. It mentions that Joshua and Caleb were the only men from their generation permitted to enter the Promised Land after the 40 years of wandering.
nq_2757_2.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document includes 'Joshua', who is identified as one of the spies who believed in the conquest of the Promised Land and was eventually allowed to enter it.
nq_2757_2.Key Information Matching: The document provides context about Joshua's role and his belief in the Israelites' ability to take the Promised Land, which aligns with his leadership in leading them there.
nq_2757_2.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document implies that Joshua was a key figure in leading the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_2.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides background information on the spies' reports and the subsequent wandering, which adds context to Joshua's role.
nq_2757_2.Explanation: The document is directly related to the query as it mentions Joshua's role and belief in the conquest of the Promised Land, which supports the answer that Joshua took the Israelites to the Promised Land. The document provides substantial context and background information relevant to the query.

ott_16235_1.Query Analysis: The query asks about the individual or group who led the Israelites to the Promised Land, a significant event in biblical history.
ott_16235_1.Answer Analysis: The answer identifies Joshua as the person who led the Israelites to the Promised Land.
ott_16235_1.Document Content Analysis: The document lists various films submitted for the 48th Academy Awards in the category of Best Foreign Language Film in 1976, including their countries of origin, titles, directors, and nomination status.
ott_16235_1.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document does not contain any of the extracted query keywords such as 'Israelites', 'Promised Land', or 'Joshua'.
ott_16235_1.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not mention 'Joshua' or any related terms from the answer.
ott_16235_1.Key Information Matching: There is no key information in the document that matches the query or the answer. The document is focused on film submissions for an awards ceremony and does not touch on historical or biblical topics.
ott_16235_1.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not contain any information relevant to the query.
ott_16235_1.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: No, the document provides no context or additional information that could help infer details about the Israelites or their journey to the Promised Land.
ott_16235_1.Explanation: The document is entirely unrelated to the query. It discusses film submissions for an awards ceremony and lacks any connection to biblical history or the specific event of the Israelites reaching the Promised Land. Therefore, it is deemed irrelevant.

nq_2757_3.Query Analysis: The query asks for the individual(s) who led the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_3.Answer Analysis: The answer identifies Joshua as the leader who took the Israelites to the Promised Land.
nq_2757_3.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the spies sent to explore the land of Canaan, the differing reports they brought back, and the roles of Joshua and Caleb. It highlights Joshua's leadership, his agreement with Caleb about conquering the land, and his eventual role as Moses' successor in leading the Israelites into the Promised Land.
nq_2757_3.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Israelites', 'Promised Land', and 'Joshua' in the context of leading the Israelites.
nq_2757_3.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document explicitly mentions 'Joshua' and his role in leading the Israelites into the Promised Land.
nq_2757_3.Key Information Matching: The document provides detailed information about Joshua's role, including his leadership in taking the Israelites to the Promised Land, which directly matches the key information required by the query.
nq_2757_3.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document directly states that Joshua led the Israelites into the Promised Land.
